title: Macomb County All Academic honorees named
body_text:
Class A
JACOB TKACZYK
Anchor Bay High School
Principal: Jeffrey LaPerriere
Parents: Eva Tkaczyk and Arthur Tkaczyk
A 4.0 student at Anchor Bay, he earned a 1480 on the SAT. Future plans include possibly attending the University of Michigan to major in computer science/engineering.
Jacob is an Athletic Department Digital Media Intern, DECA chapter vice president and captain of the track team. Honors received include AP Scholar with Distinction, valedictorian, DECA State finalist and National Rural and Small Town Scholar.
He said his parents, Eva and Arthur Tkaczyk have been influential in his academic career. “They’ve given me everything. I’d like to give it all back tenfold one day”, along with his seventh grade football coaches Doug Zielecki and Tony Hall. “Believed in me to be a starting running back and motivated me to continue to work hard to achieve the things I want.”
GJONPJER KOLA
Chippewa Valley High School
Principal: Todd Distelrath
Parents: Pjerin and Dila Kola
A 4.0 student at Chippewa Valley, he earned a 1470 on the SAT. Future plans include attending the University of Michigan’s College of Engineering to major in engineering.
Gjonpjer has been involved as president of the school chess club, as a math tutor for any subject or grade and National Honors Society. Honors received include AP Scholar with Distinction, Summa Cum Laude and class rank 1.
He said, “My AP United States and European History teacher, Mr. Brian Eovaldi, has influenced me the most in my academic career. His lectures on Western history taught me to appreciate the beauty of humanistic pursuit and thus pursuing knowledge. This, coupled with his wisdom, led to my developing a philosophy in which academic success is one of its chief virtues.”
LOGAN LEITCH
Chippewa Valley High School
Principal: Todd Distelrath
Parents: Elizabeth Leitch and Benjamin Leitch
A 4.0 student at Chippewa Valley, he earned a 1440 on the SAT. Future plans include attending Michigan Tech University to major in cybersecurity.
Logan has been involved with volunteering with his church and in the Teen Coalition Teen Council. Honors received include Chippewa Valley High School choirs Directors Award, Division 1 State Solo and Ensemble ranking and Honor Roll
He said his choir teacher, Mr. James Pecar, has been the most influential in his academic career. “He taught me that school isn’t just work, but an experience to have fun with.”
SARAH NSEIR
Chippewa Valley High School
Principal: Todd Distelrath
Parents: Shelly Nseir and Sami Nseir
A 4.0 student at Chippewa Valley, she earned a 1440 on the SAT. Future plans include attending the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor to major in aerospace engineering.
Sarah has been involved with I.AM. Robot and A Beautiful Me STEM Camp, Lego Robot Girl Scouts camp, Macomb Community College FRC Competition set up and tear down. Honors received include the FIRST Dean’s List, Awardee in the Elegoo Robots on the Road Autonomous Robot Challenge, interviewee for Detroit Driven, two year Solo and Ensemble state qualifier and an Honor Roll student.
Sarah said her father, Sami Nseir, has been the most influential in her academic career. “My father immigrated from Lebanon when he was a teenager. With little help (and while working minimum wage jobs), he earned his citizenship, a GED and an associate degree. Then he married my mother, started a family and now works as an automatic systems control designer. Through stories and my own eyes, I have witnessed my dad create a life that he can be proud of — regardless of the obstacles in his way. His actions have taught me that hard work, grit and determination are required for success. This motivates me to excel in academics because the hard work I put in today will grow into a future that will bring me joy.”
LAUREN BLASE
Cousino High School
Principal: Andre Buford
Parents: Russel and Jennifer Blase
A 4.8 student at Cousino, she earned a 1440 on the SAT. Future plans include attending Kettering University to major in mechanical engineering.
Lauren has been involved with Relay for Life, I Heart Dogs Rescue Center and the Salvation Army Bed and Bread Club. Honors received include first place in the Detroit Science Fair Physics and Astronomy, second place in the Butcher Science Fair physics and L.I.T.E.S. scholarship recipient.
She said her physics teacher, Mr. McMillan has been the most influential in her academic career. “He has encouraged me to have fun learning by basing my research through topics that interest me.”
NOAH CAFAGNA
Cousino High School
Principal: Andre Buford
Parents: Harmonie Cafagna and Dave Cafagna
A 4.731 student at Cousino, he earned a 1450 on the SAT. Future plans include attending the University of Michigan to major in mechanical engineering.
Noah has been involved with Michigan Youth Leadership Conference, National Honors Society and Mission MMSJC. Honors received include National Merit Scholarship Commended Student, 2021 Michigan Statistics Poster Competition Honorable Mention, 2022 Michigan High School Athletic Association baseball All-Academic team, US Metric Association award at SEFMD.
He said, “The person who has been most influential in my academic career is my father, Dave Cafagna. He has been a constant positive influence on my work ethic in and out of school. Witnessing his leadership in his work and through coaching has inspired me to work hard and be a strong leader in the classroom and in sports.”
CHLOE HILGENDORF
Dakota High School
Principal: Kevin Koskos
Parents: Kris and Gina Hilgendorf
A 4.130 student at Dakota, she earned a 1460 on the SAT. Future plans include attending the University of Michigan or Michigan State University Honors College/Lyman Briggs to major in biology (pre-med).
Chloe has been involved as treasurer of the Senior Class Council, probation officer for the National Honors Society and as a member of the Coalition Teen Council. Honors received include AP Scholar Award from College Board, Honor Roll and Summa Cum Laude.
She said, “My parents, Kris and Gina Hilgendorf, influenced me the most in my academic career by always supporting and encouraging me throughout my life. I want to thank them for always believing in me and teaching me I can do anything I set my mind to.”
SAARIM IGBAL
Dakota High School
Principal: Kevin Koskos
Parents: Shumaila Igbal and Asit Igbal
A 4.3 student at Dakota, he earned a 1530 on the SAT. Future plans include attending the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor to major in molecular biology.
Saarim has been involved with the community as a volunteer at the Autism Spectrum Disorder Friendship Club for two years. Honors received include National Merit Finalist, , Class rank 1, state medalist for HOSA and Da Vinci Award for best Science Olympian in the region.
He said, “My friend’s parent, Kimberly Popso has influenced me the most because she taught me how to put in effort and dedication despite the obstacles that are in front of you.”
JOHN PETERS
Dakota High School
Principal: Kevin Koskos
Parents: Janet Peters and Anthony Peters Jr.
A 4.167 student at Dakota, he earned a 1460 on the SAT. Future plans include attending the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor to major in engineering.
John has been involved with the community as a member of National Honors Society, umpiring Little League baseball and Altar Serving at St. Sharbel Maronite Catholic Church. Honors received include Cougar Academic award for cross country, Math Honors Society, Most Improved Award for cross country, AP Scholar with Distinction, Summa Cum Laude..
He said, “My grandmother, Ann Scapini, influenced me greatly during my academic career. The love and support she showed me throughout her life inspired me to persevere towards my goals and make her proud.”
DANIEL PETKOSKI
Dakota High School
Principal: Kevin Koskos
Parents: Biljana Petkoski and Goran Petkoski
A 4.153 student at Dakota, he earned a 1470 on the SAT. Future plans include attending college to major in computer science.
Daniel has been involved with the community with National Honors Society tutoring and as scorekeeper for a martial arts club. Honors received include AP Scholar with Distinction, Mu Alpha Theta member, National Honor Society member and being on the honor roll all four years.
He said his mom, Biljana Petkoski has been the most influential in his academic career. “My mom always tried to help me whenever I needed help and supported me as I grew. She also inspired me to do well in my classes.”
JOSHUA SOSNOSKI
Dakota High School
Principal: Kevin Koskos
Parents: Magda Sosnowski and Ed Sosnowski
A 4.116 student at Dakota, he earned a 1490 on the SAT. Future plans include attending the University of Michigan to major in aerospace engineering.
Joshua has been involved with the community with volunteering at Our Lady of Czestochowa Church, coaching ice hockey goalies and as a member of National Honors Society. . Honors received include 2022 You Travel Hockey state champion, 2023 Macomb Area Conference All-Star First Team, 2023 All State Academic Team, and 2023 Chippewa Valley United Team Most Valuable Player.
He said his mother, Magda Sosnowski, has been the most influential in his academic career. She immigrated here from Poland in high school and passed English class with prior experience with the language. I have always believed that if she could that than I have excuse for not acing my classes.”
EVA STEVANOVIC
Dakota High School
Principal: Kevin Koskos
Parents: Dragan Stevanovic and Aorica Markovic
A 4.139 student at Dakota, she earned a 1440 on the SAT. Future plans include attending the University of Michigan College of Engineering to major in computer science.
Eva has been involved as a member of National Honors Society and Spanish Honors Society. Honors received include first person to be awarded first team All-State for tennis at Dakota, Macomb County Most Valuable Player for tennis, MAC White Most Valuable Player for tennis, AP Scholar Award and Academic All-State for tennis.
She said, “Zonica Markovic and Dragan Stevanovic, my parents, have influenced me most in my academic career because they helped me discover my competitiveness and drive for learning at a young age and they have supported me through the arduous parts of my academic career.”
JACOB GERBINO
DeLaSalle Collegiate
Principal: Keith Kalinowski
Parents: Thomas Gerbino and Katherine Gerbino
A 4.169 student at DeLaSalle Collegiate, he earned a 1440 on the SAT. Future plans include attending the University of Michigan to major in aerospace engineering.
Jacob has been a memberthe Mock Trial Team, Lasallian community service and Student Council. Honors received include Academic All-State for varsity football, National Honors Society, Scholastic All-Catholic, College Board AP Scholar with Distinction and NMSQT Letter of Commendation.
He said: “Both of my parents have influenced my academic career the most by instilling the value of hard work into me. My work ethic comes from them so I can achieve the best that I can. They have provided me with so many other opportunities to learn new things I can never thank them enough.”
DIVYA BARTLEY
Eisenhower High School
Principal: Brandon Manzella
Parents: Uday Bartley and James Bartley
A 3.970 student at Eisenhower, she earned a 1490 on the SAT. Future plans include attending college to major in physics.
Divya has been involved with Science Olympiad. Honors received include AP Scholar awards, valedictorian and National Honors Society.
She said, “My parents have influenced me the most in my academic career by setting high expectations and encouraging me.”
LOGAN BERGLER
Eisenhower High School
Principal: Brandon Manzella
Parents: Monica Bergler and Ken Bergler
A 4.0 student at Eisenhower, he earned a 1520 on the SAT. Future plans include attending the University of Michigan or Michigan State University to major in computer science.
Logan has been involved in the community, as supervisor for an event for Division A Science Olympiad and coach for Division B Science Olympiad. Honors received include AP Scholar with Distinction, National Merit Commended Student, Macomb County second team Division 1 tennis and placed in several events at the state level for Science Olympiad.
He said “My mother, Monica Bergler, has influenced me the most throughout my academic career. She has always inspired me to do my best and push myself to levels I did not know I could achieve. She also taught me a great work ethic that helped me always stay on top of things and get things done.”
LUCAS DESOUSA
Eisenhower High School
Principal: Brandon Manzella
Parents: Marina DeSousa and Joe DeSousa
A 3.938 student at Eisenhower, he earned a 1470 on the SAT. Future plans include attending the University of Michigan to major in biomedical engineering.
Lucas has been involved in the community, volunteering at Macomb Humane Society as a canine companion, sorting medical supplies for the World Medical Relief and tutoring Utica Community School students. Honors received include varsity cross country, varsity swim, National Honors Society and AP Scholars Award with Distinction.
He said that Simarjit Singh has been the most influential in his academic career. “He gave me a competitive environment for me to thrive.”
TYLER FARMER
Eisenhower High School
Principal: Brandon Manzella
Parent: Jennifer Farmer
A 4.0 student at Eisenhower, he earned a 1450 on the SAT. Future plans include attending the University of Michigan. He is undecided on a major, but considering mechanical, aerospace and electrical engineering.
Tyler has been involved with the community, having done community service with his dad restoring Edsel Ford’s old farmhouses, working at Mr. C’s car wash vacuuming out people’s cars and helping his grandfather inspect houses for people before they purchased them.
Honors received include National Junior Honor Society member in ninth grade and received certificate for completing all service hours, Honor Roll every year in high school, chosen for the Macomb All-Academic team and granted the HAIL scholarship at the University of Michigan for free tuition for four years.
He said “My parents, Ronald Farmer and Jennifer Farmerwere my greatest influences. They always believed I would be capable of great things and they taught me to believe it too. They and I have been through a lot over the past several years and their continuous strength and perseverance motivates me to work hard and chase my dreams. My parents are my greatest inspiration and everything I do, I do to make them proud.”
KYLE KIRSCH
Eisenhower High School
Principal: Brandon Manzella
Parents: Stacey Jennifer Kirsch and Matthew Kirsch
A 3.967 student at Eisenhower, he earned a 1470 on the SAT. Future plans include attending the University of Michigan to major in biology.
Kyle has been involved in the community. Kyle has been a volunteer at the Humane Society of Macomb, National Honors Society and volunteering at Trinity Lutheran Church. Honors received include Cross Country Perseverance award, AAPPL proficient German speaker, AP Scholar and valedictorian.
He said his parents, Jennifer and Matthew Kirsch, have been the most influential in his academic career. “They always encouraged me to do well in school academically. They showed me the hard work it would take to be accepted at the University of Michigan.”
HAILEY NIGHTINGALE
Eisenhower High School
Principal: Brandon Manzella
Parents: Christina Nightingale and Nathan Nightingale
A 4.0 student at Eisenhower, she earned a 1500 on the SAT. Future plans include attending Oakland University, though yet undecided on a field of study.
Honors received include National Merit Scholarship finalist and AP Scholar award.
She said her parents have been the most influential in her academic career.
DANIEL PERKOVIC
Eisenhower High School
Principal: Brandon Manzella
Parent: Marina Perkovic
A 4.0 student at Eisenhower, he earned a 1480 on the SAT. Future plans include attending Oakland University or the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor to major in political science.
Daniel has been involved with National Honors Society and Youth for Christ. Honors received include AP Scholar with Honor, Silver Medal National Spanish Exam Level 3 and Excellent Monologue acting at Michigan Thespian Festival.
He said his mother, Marina Perkovic has been the most influential in his academic career. “Ever since I was a little kid, my mother always told me the necessity and importance of an education. She moved to the United States to provide me with a better life than hers as well as a college education. “As a result, I am grateful for all that she has done for me as well as pushing me on academics.”
JACOB WALTERS
Eisenhower High School
Principal: Brandon Manzella
Parents: Abra Walters and Jeff Walters
A 4.0 student at Eisenhower, he earned a 1510 on the SAT. Future plans include attending the University of Michigan to major in nuclear engineering.
Jacob has been involved in the community by helping with the warming center at a homeless shelter, helping at elementary school Science Olympiad and helped clean Switzer Elementary School’s sixth grade graduation. Honors received include AP Scholar with Distinction, valedictorian, academic Scholar Board of Education recognition and HAIL scholarship.
He said his parents have been the most influential in his academic career. “They encouraged the best from me and my brothers with positive words and support wherever and whenever I needed it (unconditional love). The thoughts of helping them retire in comfort also heavily influenced my effort in school.”
PEYTON WERNER
Eisenhower High School
Principal: Brandon Manzella
Parents: Toni Werner and Brad Werner
A 4.0 student at Eisenhower, she earned a 1450 on the SAT. Future plans include attending Oakland University to major in finance through the Business Honors program.
Peyton has been involved as the 50th anniversary chairman in Eisenhower’s student council, organizing events to celebrate 50 generations of Eisenhower graduates and recognize the impact they have had on the school, as a part of a district-wide, student-led Instagram page with students from other high schools in the Utica Community Schools district, with the goal of unite the large district and improve communication between the schools and as a member of project unify, volunteering time towards helping and improving the LCCE program. Honors received include valedictorian, Oakland University Platinum Presidential Scholarship recipient and MASC/MAHS Award of Excellence.
She said, “My mom has had the greatest impact on me. She hasn’t let challenges or setbacks stop her from achieving great things and becoming successful. She plays a big part in who I am today. In addition to inspiring me to succeed, she has offered me the constant support and reassurance I have needed throughout my academic career.”
AUSTIN WILLIAMS
Eisenhower High School
Principal: Brandon Manzella
Parents: Kyle Williams and Leah Williams
A 3.967 student at Eisenhower, he earned a 1470 on the SAT. Future plans include attending Palvis Honors at Michigan Technological University or the University of Michigan to major in engineering.
Austin has been involved as vice-president of Project Outreach, a community service club, as clarinet co-section leader for Ike Marching Band and as National Honor Society member. Honors received include AP Scholar with Honors,4.08 weighted grade point average, 5 AP’s and varsity band this year, AP scores three fives, one four and German National Honor Society member.
He said Ami Agnetti, third grade teacher from Switzer Elementary, has been the most influential in his academic career. “Miss Agnetti has a tremendous effect on me. She took the time to personally know me and tackle my challenges. She retaught me how to write-I did not know how to start letters at the top and made me, a kid who had barely read, grow to love reading. She even helped me foster advanced math skills.”
LUKAS ZAHURANIC
Eisenhower High School
Principal: Brandon Manzella
Parents: Kristy Zahuranic and Michael Zahuranic
A 4.0 student at Eisenhower, he earned a 1480 on the SAT. Future plans include attending the University of Michigan College of Engineering to major in mechanical engineering.
Lukas has been involved working various events at church, tutoring elementary, middle school and high school students and as a member of National Honors Society. Honors received include National Merit Finalist, varsity baseball captain, AP Scholar with Honors and All-State first team academics for baseball.
He said his dad, Michael Zahuranic has been the most influential in his academic career. “He has influenced me the most because he has always pushed me to do the best possible and inspired me by proving through hard work, I can get the life I want.”
BUSHRA KHANAM
Fitzgerald High School
Principal: Amanda Clor
Parents: Ayesha Khanam and Mohammad Ebad Khan
A 4.1 student at Fitzgerald, she earned a 1310 on the SAT. Future plans include attending the University of Michigan, though is undecided on a field of study.
Bushra has been involved with NSCDC, arranged and distributed food to those who needed assistance and through National Honor Society arranged donations for Afghanistani refugees. Honors received include Baurbugh Scholar, earned Honor Roll and earned Principal’s Honor Roll.
She said, “My family inspired me to be better and always persevere.”
JESSICA REINHART
Fraser High School
Principal: Ryan D. Sines
Parents: Jennifer Reinhart and Steven Reinhart
A 4.0 student at Fraser, she earned a 1450 on the SAT. Future plans include attending Michigan Technological University, though yet undecided on a field of study.
Jessica has been involved with fundraising for Turning Point Macomb, volunteering for the Humane Society of Macomb and local park clean up. Honors received include National Art Honor Society, Excellent Award for the Science and Engineering Fair of Metropolitan Detroit, Commendation for National Merit Scholarship and Quill and Scroll Journalism Honor Society.
She said her mother has been the most influential in her academic career. “Jennifer Reinhart, my mother, for all the time and sacrifices she has made for me. She’s always reminded me to enjoy life and take care of myself. Thank you!”
ETHAN AHMED
Henry Ford II High School
Principal: Lori Singleton
Parents: Kabir Ahmed and Syeda Ahmed
A 4.24 student at Henry Ford II, he earned a 1480 on the SAT. Future plans include attending the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor to major in biochemistry or microbiology.
Ethan has been involved with volunteering at his mosque and school events. Honors received include AP Scholar with Distinction and Congressional App Challenge winner.
He said his dad, Kabir Ahmed, has been the most influential in his academic career. “My dad has always worked hard to make my family happy and continued to support me throughout my academic career. By working hard to support us, he encouraged me to work my hardest and push myself to make my family proud.”
RACHEL SAMSON
Henry Ford II High School
Principal: Lori Singleton
Parents: Samson Baby and Bency Samson
A 4.22 student at Henry Ford II, she earned a 1530 on the SAT. Future plans include attending college to major in biochemistry.
Rachel has been involved as a medical intern at Clinton Women’s Healthcare, HOSA Future Health Professional treasurer and member of the Key Club. Honors received include AP Scholar with Distinction.
She said, “Ms. Debra Horger, my biology teacher, has been the most influential in my academic career. Her knowledge and passion for learning has truly inspired me to pursue a career in medicine.”
DIEGO ALVREZ
International Academy of Macomb
Principal: Dr. Laura Strong
Parents: Jose Alvrez and Esmeralda Rodriguez
A 4.0 student at the International Academy of Macomb, he earned a 1570 on the SAT. Future plans include attending the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to major in electrical engineering.
Diego has been leading Girl Scout STEM camps, team 4810 First Robotics, volunteering for summer STEM activities for a variety of age groups. Honors received include AATG National German Exam Finalist Gold Medal, PAD Prize winner program German summer scholarship, NMSQT semifinalist recognition and SAT – National Hispanic recognition program.
He said his grandfather, Ruben Rodriquez has been the most influential in his academic career. “He always shared creativity and perseverance in the automotive field and showed me what it really means to try and what an engineer is really all about.”
NICHOLAS FLESER
International Academy of Macomb
Principal: Dr. Laura Strong
Parents: Octavian and Ruxandra Fleser
A 4.0 student at the International Academy of Macomb, he earned a 1490 on the SAT. Future plans include attending the Carol Davila University of Medicine and Pharmacy to major in biomedical sciences.
Nicholas has been a board member of SHN, National Honor Society and SNHS. Honors received include National Merit Scholarship and a finalist of National Vivace Honors piano competition.
VIRAYRE GANDOTRA
International Academy of Macomb
Principal: Dr. Laura Strong
Parents: Sandeep Gandotra and Puneeti Gandotra
A 4.4 student at the International Academy of Macomb, he earned a 1470 on the SAT. Future plans include attending Oakland University or the University of Michigan to major in biomedical science.
Virayre has been involved with Link Crew, HOSA and SNHS Honors received include honors from SHNS, National Honors Society and Spanish National Honors Society.
He said his grandmother has been the most influential in his academic career as a former gynecologist who emphasized purity and honesty to help others and Dr. Jonathan Swetech, who is his mentor for what it means to be a good doctor and leader.
JASKARAN RANDHAWA
International Academy of Macomb
Principal: Dr. Laura Strong
Parents: Aneel Randhawa and Jasdeep Randhawa
A 3.9 student at the International Academy of Macomb, he earned a 1560 on the SAT. Future plans include attending the University of Michigan to major in biomedical engineering.
Jaskaran has been involved as student producer for IAM Theatre, on Dakota’s tennis team and dental terminology competitor for Michigan HOSA. Honors received include Key Club SLC’s Sandy Ninninger Outstanding Key Clubber of the Year, Letter of Commendation from National Merit Scholarship competition.
He said his parents and sister have been the most influential in his academic career. “My parents and sister for always supporting me through everything.”
VALERIIA TEODOROVYCH
International Academy of Macomb
Principal: Dr. Laura Strong
Parents: Olga Levin and Sergei Levin
A 4.0 student at the International Academy of Macomb, she earned a 1470 on the SAT. Future plans include attending the University of Michigan to major in biopsychology, cognition and neuroscience, though has not yet made a decision on career path.
Valeriia has been involved with the community Ukraine Fundraiser through Global Giving, volunteering for Humane Society of Macomb and organizing a talent show at the school. Honors received include Michigan School Band and Orchestra Association Division I rating, Michigan School Band and Orchestra Association Division II State rating and Risk Taker Award
She said her mother Olga Levin has been the most influential in her academic career. “She has always been by my side.”
OLIVIA TREMBERTH
International Academy of Macomb
Principal: Dr. Laura Strong
Parents: Mark Tremberth and Susan Tremberth
A 3.9 student at the International Academy of Macomb, she earned a 1510 on the SAT. Future plans include attending the University of Michigan to major in civil engineering.
Olivia has been involved with the community with a dog toy drive for charity, a Camp Invention counselor and Motor City Mitten Mission homeless shelter mats.
Honors received include Macomb Area Conference ALL-American award for softball.
She said, “My parents, for always encouraging me to be curious.”
CHRISTINA CANTIN
Lake Shore High School
Principal: Jenelle Bross
Parents: Dawn Cantin and Phil Cantin
A 3.89 student at Lake Shore, she earned a 1240 on the SAT. Future plans include attending one more year at Early College at Macomb then attend the University of Michigan to major in computer science.
Christina has been involved with the community, having job shadowed music teachers and helped with children in grades K-8. Honors received include Winter 2022 and Fall 2023 Dean’s List at Macomb Community College, five First Divisions at Michigan School Band and Orchestra Association District 16 Solo and Ensemble competition, two first divisions at Michigan School Band and Orchestra Association State Solo and Ensemble competitions, drum major for two years and National Honor Society member.
She said her band director in middle school, Christopher Kauffold, has been the most influential in her academic career. “He made me learn to feel confident in myself and let me express myself through music.”
AVA COSTALES
Lakeview High School
Principal:Scott Kapla
Parent: Genevieve Taylor
A 4.0 student at Lakeview, she earned a 1470 on the SAT. Future plans include attending the University of Michigan to major in biological sciences (pre-med).
Ava said the most meaningful community service she has done was the Macomb Feed the Need. Honors received include holding the office of National Honors Society president, first team All State for softball, College Board AP Scholar Award and Frederick G.L. Huetwell scholarship recipient.
She said, “My mom instilled work ethic in me from a very young age through both academics and athletics and she has always been my biggest supporter in everything I have worked toward.”
ANGELINA BURSON
L’Anse Creuse High School
Principal: Dr. Major Mickens
Parents: Rie Burson and Mark Burson
A 4.0 student at L’Anse Creuse High School, she earned a 1580 on the SAT. Future plans include attending college to major in environmental engineering.
Angelina has been involved with the community as a two time Wigs for Kids donator, Haven Place Youth Camp and Heart Walk. Honors received include National Merit Finalist, valedictorian, achievement award for a perfect score on the ACT and first place Advanced Digits of Pi contest (1218 digits).
She said Chandler Missig, her Honors and AP Biology teacher has been the most influential in her academic career. “Ms. Missing was the first teacher I saw every day in ninth grade and she set the tone for my academic performance throughout the school with her enthusiastic attitude and rigorous coursework that prepared me for advanced-level classes.”
SAMANTHA DECEUNINCK
L’Anse Creuse High School
Principal: Dr. Major Mickens
Parents: Marie DeCeuninck and Douglas DeCeuninck
A 4.0 student at L’Anse Creuse High School, she earned a 1490 on the SAT. Future plans include attending the University of Michigan to major in biology.
Samantha has been involved as a member of the L’Anse Creuse High School soccer team (varsity 2021-2023), L’Anse Creuse High School bowling team (varsity 2022) and volunteering at the school concession stand. Honors received include Scholastic Achievement Award, AP Scholar Award and Lancer basketball award
She said, “The person who influenced my academic career the most is my sister, Maggie DeCeuninck. Whether she knows it or not, she has always been my biggest role model and she has been so supportive of me through all my academic endeavors.”
BEN PUZZUOLI
L’Anse Creuse High School
Principal: Dr. Major Mickens
Parents: Amy Puzzuoli and Adam Puzzuoli
A 4.0 student at L’Anse Creuse High School, he earned a 1510 on the SAT. Future plans include attending the University of Michigan to major in biology.
Ben has been involved in the community with the National Honors Society, MCREST and Mu Alpha Theta tutoring. Honors received include National Honors Society president, salutatorian, cross country state qualifier, DECA state qualifier, and four year MST achievement awards.
He said, “My dad has had the greatest influence on my academic career by instilling the values of discipline and work ethic within me from a young age.”
ANNDEE GEDDES
L’Anse Creuse High School North
Principal: Meredith Beard
Parents: Julie Geddes and Timothy Geddes
A 4.0 student at L’Anse Creuse High School North, she earned a 1540 on the SAT. Future plans include attending the University of Michigan to major in actuarial science.
AnnDee has been involved with the community participating in MCREST and helping to prepare meals for the homeless and tutoring for National Honors Society and Mu Alpha Theta. Honors received include salutatorian, commended for PSAT National Merit, cross country/track academic all-state and celebration of excellence (all years).
She said Jarrett Geddes, her older brother, has been the most influential in her academic career. “He has always believed in me and pushed me to be my best all throughout high school.”
MATTHEW KIEWSKI
L’Anse Creuse High School North
Principal: Meredith Beard
Parents: Karen Kiewski and James Kiewski
A 3.975 student at L’Anse Creuse High School North, he earned a 1480 on the SAT. Future plans include attending Cornell University to major in biomedical engineering.
Matthew has been involved with the community creating and coordinating Socktober, a sock drive in October for local warming shelters for two years, tutoring students in math and science and tennis coaching as assistant coach to the L’Anse Creuse Middle School North tennis team. Honors received include MASC/MAHS Student of the Year nominee, AP Scholar with Distinction award, MST achievement award, LCN varsity tennis academic achievement award and Scholastic Achievement award.
He said, “Ms. Chandler Missig was my honors and AP Biology teacher, who serves as a mentor to me and encouraged me to step outside of my comfort zone and grow into the leader I am today. Her encouragement has enabled me to achieve my goals.”
BRIAN MEI
L’Anse Creuse High School North
